conclusion: Determine the length of the arc on AC where light rays undergo total internal reflection and cannot exit through AB or BC.
The cross-section ABCO is a square with side length R. The arc AC is part of a circle with radius R and center O.
The refractive index of the material is n = 2.
The critical angle for total internal reflection is calculated as θc = 30°.
For light to exit through AB or BC, the angle of incidence must be less than the critical angle θc = 30°.
If the angle of incidence at the arc AC results in an angle of refraction greater than 30°, the light will undergo total internal reflection.
The maximum angle θ for which light can exit without TIR is when the angle of refraction is exactly 30°.
The angle θ at which light just grazes the critical angle at the boundary is 60°.
Any light incident at an angle greater than 60° will undergo total internal reflection.
The arc AC subtends an angle of 90° at the center O.
The portion of the arc where light undergoes TIR corresponds to angles from 60° to 90°.
The length of the arc where light cannot exit is calculated as (30°/360°) × 2πR = πR/6.
The length of the arc where the light rays cannot directly exit through AB or BC is πR/6.
